<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 279, 170, 290]]<|/det|> **PHYSICS** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 393, 311]]<|/det|> Paper 2 AS Level Structured Questions <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 339, 415, 351]]<|/det|> Candidates answer on the Question Paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 360, 367, 371]]<|/det|> No Additional Materials are required. <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 393, 388, 405]]<|/det|> # READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 419, 718, 431]]<|/det|> Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 434, 325, 445]]<|/det|> Write in dark blue or black pen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 448, 503, 460]]<|/det|> You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 462, 504, 474]]<|/det|> Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 476, 380, 488]]<|/det|> DO **NOT** WRITE IN ANY BARCODES. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 503, 256, 514]]<|/det|> Answer **all** questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 359, 540]]<|/det|> Electronic calculators may be used. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 543, 767, 555]]<|/det|> You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 568, 605, 580]]<|/det|> At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 583, 757, 595]]<|/det|> The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 124, 87]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 102, 672, 560]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{ms}^{- 1}\) permeability of free space \(\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{Hm}^{- 1}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{- 12}\mathrm{Fm}^{- 1}\) \((\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{- 1})\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60\times 10^{- 19}\mathrm{C}\) the Planck constant \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{Js}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1u = 1.66\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{- 31}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38\times 10^{- 23}\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67\times 10^{- 11}\mathrm{Nm}^{2}\mathrm{kg}^{- 2}\) acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81\mathrm{ms}^{- 2}\)

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 167, 88]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 106, 560, 145]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 163, 525, 179]]<|/det|>
\[W = p\Delta V\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 193, 537, 223]]<|/det|>
\[\phi = -\frac{Gm}{r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 235, 521, 252]]<|/det|>
\[p = \rho gh\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 263, 560, 295]]<|/det|>
\[p = \frac{1}{3}\frac{Nm}{V}\langle c^2\rangle\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 305, 540, 321]]<|/det|>
\[a = -\omega^2 x\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 339, 615, 375]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = \nu_{0}\cos \omega t\] \[\nu = \pm \omega \sqrt{(\nu_{0}^{2} - x^{2})}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 384, 536, 419]]<|/det|>
\[f_{0} = \frac{f_{s}V}{\nu \pm \nu_{s}}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 430, 540, 464]]<|/det|>
\[V = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[427, 472, 627, 490]]<|/det|>
\[1 / C = 1 / C_{1} + 1 / C_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 504, 595, 522]]<|/det|>
\[C = C_{1} + C_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 533, 526, 559]]<|/det|>
\[W = \frac{1}{2} QV\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 575, 530, 591]]<|/det|>
\[I = Anvq\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 609, 595, 625]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_{1} + R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[427, 640, 627, 657]]<|/det|>
\[1 / R = 1 / R_{1} + 1 / R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 670, 518, 702]]<|/det|>
\[V_{H} = \frac{BI}{ntq}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 718, 560, 735]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\sin \omega t\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 750, 578, 768]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\exp (-\lambda t)\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 778, 536, 812]]<|/det|>
\[\lambda = \frac{0.693}{t_{\frac{1}{2}}}\]

<pre>Answer **all** the questions in the spaces provided.

<label>1</label>

<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 104, 265, 121]]<|/det|>
Define force.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 165, 144, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 165, 421, 183]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 227, 573, 245]]<|/det|>
The force \(F\) between two point charges is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 250, 544, 281]]<|/det|>
\[F = \frac{Q_1Q_2}{4\pi r^2\epsilon}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 305, 440, 322]]<|/det|>
where \(Q_{1}\) and \(Q_{2}\) are the charges,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[213, 322, 534, 337]]<|/det|>
\(r\) is the distance between the charges,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[213, 337, 755, 353]]<|/det|>
\(\epsilon\) is a constant that depends on the medium between the charges.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 368, 641, 384]]<|/det|>
Use the above expression to determine the base units of \(\epsilon\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 645, 918, 661]]<|/det|>
<form>base units ................................................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 675, 920, 693]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 561, 90]]<|/det|>
State the principle of conservation of momentum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[855, 165, 918, 183]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 196, 146, 214]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 196, 918, 228]]<|/det|>
A stationary firework explodes into three different fragments that move in a horizontal plane, as illustrated in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[308, 238, 682, 393]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 406, 531, 424]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 2.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 439, 804, 455]]<|/det|>
The fragment of mass \(3.0M\) has a velocity of \(7.0 \text{m s}^{-1}\) perpendicular to line AB.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 453, 770, 469]]<|/det|>
The fragment of mass \(2.0M\) has a velocity of \(6.0 \text{m s}^{-1}\) at angle \(\theta\) to line AB.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 467, 770, 483]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 500, 180, 518]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<form>\(\theta =\) ............................................................ ° [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 685, 180, 704]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 686, 348, 702]]<|/det|>
Calculate the ratio

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[327, 710, 667, 743]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{\text{kinetic energy of fragment of mass } 2.0M}{\text{kinetic energy of fragment of mass } 1.5M}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[527, 857, 918, 873]]<|/det|>
<form>ratio = ........................................................................... [2]

<mark>[Total: 7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 917, 106]]<|/det|>
A child on a sledge slides down a steep hill and then travels in a straight line up an ice-covered slope, as illustrated in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 115, 851, 240]]<|/det|>
<center>Fig. 3.1 (not to scale)</center>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 293, 918, 339]]<|/det|>
The sledge passes point A with speed \(18 \text{m s}^{-1}\) at time \(t = 0\) and then comes to rest at point B. The child applies a brake to the sledge at point B. The brake does not keep the sledge stationary and it immediately slides back down the slope towards A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 354, 897, 370]]<|/det|>
The variation with time \(t\) of the velocity \(v\) of the sledge from \(t = 0\) to \(t = 24\) s is shown in Fig. 3.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 381, 853, 600]]<|/det|>
<center>Fig. 3.2</center>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 649, 146, 667]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 649, 613, 666]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[528, 710, 917, 726]]<|/det|>
<form>time = ............................................................ $s$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 710, 918, 726]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 288, 918, 306]]<|/det|>
<form>displacement = .................................................................... $m$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[897, 288, 918, 306]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 320, 887, 338]]<|/det|>
Show that the acceleration of the sledge as it moves from B back towards A is \(0.50 \text{m s}^{-2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 444, 920, 463]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 475, 148, 492]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 475, 918, 508]]<|/det|>

Determine

<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[556, 893, 918, 910]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta =\) ............................................................ °

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[897, 893, 918, 911]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 918, 120]]<|/det|>
The child on the sledge blows a whistle between \(t = 4.0s\) and \(t = 8.0s\) . The whistle emits sound of frequency \(900\mathrm{Hz}\) . The speed of the sound in the air is \(340\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{-1}\) . A man standing at point A hears the sound.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 135, 280, 152]]<|/det|>
Use Fig. 3.2 to

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 166, 180, 184]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 165, 705, 183]]<|/det|>
determine the initial frequency of the sound heard by the man,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 320, 917, 337]]<|/det|>
<form>initial frequency = ............................................................ Hz [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 351, 180, 369]]<|/det|>

<label>4</label>

<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 180, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

Define the wavelength of a progressive wave.

<mark>[1]

<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 257, 918, 291]]<|/det|>
A loudspeaker producing sound of constant frequency is placed near the open end of a pipe, as shown in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 298, 853, 405]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 421, 532, 438]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 4.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 453, 918, 485]]<|/det|>
A movable piston is at distance \(x\) from the open end of the pipe. Distance \(x\) is increased from \(x = 0\) by moving the piston to the left with a constant speed of \(0.75 \text{cm s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 500, 549, 516]]<|/det|>
The speed of the sound in the pipe is \(340 \text{m s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 530, 181, 549]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 530, 918, 562]]<|/det|>
A much louder sound is first heard when \(x = 4.5 \text{cm}\). Assume that there is an antinode of a stationary wave at the open end of the pipe.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 577, 603, 593]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[484, 715, 918, 732]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[464, 870, 918, 887]]<|/det|>
<form>time interval = ............................................................ $s$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 902, 918, 918]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 903, 918, 919]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 919, 106]]<|/det|>
A solid cylinder is lifted out of oil by a wire attached to a motor. Fig. 5.1 shows two different positions X and Y of the cylinder during the lifting process.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 114, 880, 361]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 374, 532, 392]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 5.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 407, 460, 422]]<|/det|>
The motor is fixed to an overhead beam.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 422, 764, 438]]<|/det|>
The cylinder has cross-sectional area \(0.018m^2\) , length \(1.2m\) and weight \(560N.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 437, 406, 453]]<|/det|>
The density of the oil is \(940kgm^{- 3}.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 467, 919, 500]]<|/det|>
Throughout the lifting process, the cylinder moves vertically upwards with a constant velocity of \(0.020m s^{- 1}\) . The viscous force of the oil acting on the cylinder is negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 514, 146, 532]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 514, 456, 530]]<|/det|>
Calculate the density of the cylinder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[505, 636, 917, 653]]<|/det|>
<form>density = .................................................... $kgm^{-3}$ [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 668, 148, 687]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 668, 772, 686]]<|/det|>
For the cylinder at position X, show that the upthrust due to the oil is 200 N.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[893, 808, 920, 826]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>
